choices.text: Medical treatment with OC (oral contraceptives) pills

questions.text: A 42 year old female presents with a complaint of menorrhagia for 4 months. On investigating, she was diagnosed with FIGO -3 stage of fibroid. She has completed her family. What is the first line of treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
FIGO -3 suggestive of intramural fibroid touching the endometrium.

  • In this case a patient complaining of menorrhagia and she doesn't want fertility, so the first line of treatment is medical treatment. Very low dose OC pills should be started. In some cases, if a patient cannot take estrogen, mirena should be inserted.
  • Surgical treatment options include abdominal myomectomy, laparoscopic myomectomy, laparoscopic radiofrequency ablation, hysteroscopic myomectomy, endometrial ablation, and abdominal, vaginal, or laparoscopic hysterectomy.
  • Serious medical conditions, such as severe anemia or ureteral obstruction, often need to be addressed surgically.

Reference: Berek & Novak's Gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 11, Page number:. 232

questions.text: A patient presents with a complaint of involuntary leakage of urine on effort or exertion like coughing, sneezing etc. If stress urinary incontinence(SUI) is suspected in this patient, all of the following are initial treatment for most types of stress urinary incontinence except
questions.solution:
• Conservative options should be offered to all patients as a first-line treatment. To optimize treatment benefits, diagnosis should be made early during the course of disease, and sometimes before onset of overt symptoms.
  • Conservative treatments are generally simple, noninvasive, readily available and inexpensive, relatively effective and with little to no side effects.
  • Examples of conservative nonpharmacologic Interventions include lifestyle modification, counseling and patient education, bladder training (or retraining), relaxation and urgency suppression, exercise training (e.g., pelvic floor muscle exercises), biofeedback, electric stimulation (Estim), pessaries, and urethral plugs.
  • Medical management of SUI is controversial. The drugs used are usually having stimulating effect on alpha adrenergic receptors but they are not FDA approved and are rarely used purely for SUI.

Topic: stress urinary incontinence

Reference: Berek & Novak's Gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 29, Page number:. 717

choices.text: Admit the patient in hospital and start IV fluids
OPD management with analgesics and antiemetics

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient of polycystic ovarian syndrome came to OPD after ovulation induction with gonadotropins. She was given inj. HCG 10,000 units for ovulation 3 days back. She is complaining about nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, and lower abdominal pain. She is vitally stable. What is your line of management?
questions.solution:
This medical condition is ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS). Patient is having mild symptoms. So outpatient management is appropriate.

Severity Classification

OHSS can be described as mild, moderate, and severe OHSS.

  • mild OHSS (grade 1 to 2) is associated with abdominal distention and discomfort with grade 2 including nausea, vomiting or diarrhea accompanied by ovary diameter of at least 5 mm.
  • Moderate or grade 3 includes grade 2 plus sonographic subclinical ascites near the liver or in the pelvis if pocket >9 mm.
  • Severe OHSS (grade 4 to 5) is associated with grade 3 plus clinical ascites, hydrothorax, or dyspnea, with grade 5 including hemoconcentration, renal insufficiency or oliguria, elevated transaminases, venous thromboembolism, or respiratory distress syndrome.

Indications for hospitalization:

Inability to tolerate oral hydration, Hemodynamic instability, Respiratory compromise, tense ascites, Hemoconcentration, leukocytosis, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, Abnormal renal or liver function, Decreased oxygen saturation

Topic: OHSS

Reference: Berek & Novak's Gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 36, Page number 2307

choices.text: Discrepancies in MCA-PSV of both fetus

questions.text: A 34 year old Hindu married female, came to a tertiary care hospital, conceived by IVF at 6 month of amenorrhea with USG fetus suggestive of differences in blood flow velocity of MCA (middle cerebral artery), and the visiting consultant was suspecting Twin anemia Polycythemia sequence in that patient. Which of the following is not associated with a patient having TAPS
questions.solution:
TAPS is a chronic fetofetal transfusion, which is characterized by significant hemoglobin differences between donor and recipient twins. The donor twin in spontaneous TAPS is anemic and usually smaller than the recipient twin, which is polycythemic. However, TAPS lacks the discrepancies in amnionic fluid volumes typical of TTTS.

  • Spontaneous TAPS can develop at any gestational age (usually after 26 weeks of gestation) and complicates 1 to 6% of monochorionic twins.
  • Iatrogenic TAPS develops in up to 13% of pregnancies after laser ablation of the placenta and usually develops within 5 weeks of a procedure. In iatrogenic TAPS, the former TTTS recipient twin usually becomes anemic, whereas the former donor becomes polycythemic.

Sonographically measuring blood flow velocity in the fetal middle cerebral artery (MCA) can accurately identify fetal anemia.

Fetoscopic selective laser ablation - A minimally invasive surgery performed on the placenta to disconnect the communicating blood vessels. This procedure, also called selective laser photocoagulation (SLPC), stops the sharing of blood from the donor to the recipient, with the goal of halting the progression of transfusion of red blood cells.

Topic: (twin anemia polycythemia sequence):

Reference:

  • William's Obstetrics 25th Edition, Chapter 45, Page number:. 880
  • https://www.chop.edu/

questions.text: Ideal sequence of reposition in uterine inversion?
questions.solution:
If the recently inverted uterus has not contracted and if the placenta has already separated, then the uterus may often be replaced by simply pushing inverted fundus by palm of hand in the direction of the long axis of vagina.

Topic: uterine inversion sequence

Reference: William's Obstetrics 25th Edition, Chapter 41, Page number. 762

questions.text: A primigravida patient came into the labour room complaining of labour pain and discharge PV. On per vaginal examination, cervix 3 cm dilated, 40% effaced, anterior position, intermediate consistency and station '-2' and leak present. What is the bishop's score of this patient and will induction be advised for this patient or not?
questions.solution:
In modified bishop scoring cervical effacement is replaced by cervical length.

Modified Bishop scoring is used and regard a score of 6 or above as favourable and predictive of high likelihood of successful induction, whereas scores below 6 warrant an attempt at ripening of the cervix.

Topic: Bishop’s score

Reference: Ian Donald's Practical Obstetric Problems, 8th Edition, Chapter 28, Page number. 580

questions.text: Remnant of mullerian in females:
questions.solution:
Remnant of wolffian duct in females:

  • Epoophoron
  • Paroophoron
  • Gartner’s duct

Remnant of mullerian duct in males:

  • Appendix of testes
  • Prostatic utricle

Remnant of mullerian duct in females:

  • Hydatid of Morgagni (parafimbrial cyst)

Topic: Remnant of mullerian duct

questions.text: Female having complain of vaginal itching and white discharge per vagina. On per speculum examination, there is curdy white discharge from vagina. Wet mount of this discharge shows image like below. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Clinical scenario suggestive of candidiasis:

  • Most common cause: Candida albicans > Candida glabrata and candida tropicalis.
  • C/f: Itching, curdy white cottage cheese discharge, redness, excoriation, severe inflammation, associated UTI
  • It can cause vaginitis, vulvitis, urethritis, but it never causes PID.
  • Risk factor: Diabetes, PCOS, obesity, HIV, steroid, antibiotic use, pregnancy
  • Investigation: On a wet mount preparation there is pseudohyphae or budding yeast present, Ph of vagina is <4.5, and whiff test is negative.
  • Treatment: Tablet fluconazole 150 mg single dose

Topic: Candidiasis

Reference: Berek & Novak's Gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 15, Page number. 887

questions.text: All of the following are causes of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism except:
questions.solution:
Turner syndrome (45,X) and its variants represent the most common form of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism in women with primary amenorrhea.

Other disorders associated with primary amenorrhea include structurally abnormal X chromosomes, mosaicism, pure gonadal dysgenesis, enzyme deficiencies that prevent normal estrogen production, and gonadotropin-receptor inactivating mutations. Individuals with these conditions have gonadal failure and cannot synthesize ovarian steroids. Gonadotropin levels are elevated because of the lack of negative estrogen feedback on the

hypothalamic–pituitary axis. Most patients with these conditions have primary amenorrhea and lack secondary sexual characteristics.

Swyer syndrome, also known as 46 XY complete (pure) gonadal dysgenesis (CGD), is a rare congenital disorder of sex development.

STREAK GONADS - FUNCTIONLESS CONNECTIVE TISSUE that DOES NOT SECRETE SEX HORMONES

~ NO NATURAL PUBERTY (e.g. MENSTRUATION, BREASTS)

~ INFERTILE

Severe damage to the ovaries before the onset of puberty can lead to ovarian insufficiency and failure to develop secondary sexual characteristics. Ovarian dysfunction can occur in association with irradiation of the ovaries, chemotherapy with alkylating agents (e.g., cyclophosphamide), or combinations of radiation and other chemotherapeutic agents.

Sheehan's syndrome occurs due to postpartum haemorrhage causing pituitary stalk necrosis. It leads to hypopituitarism. So there is decreased gonadotropins level -> hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

Topic: sheehan's syndrome

Reference: Berek & Novak's Gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 34, Page number:2047

questions.text: An intern, currently posted in the Obstetrics and Gynecology department, was asked what is the upper gestational limit for Medical termination of Pregnancy. Which of the following option correctly describes the same?
questions.solution:
According to the MTP Act (amendment),2021, the upper gestational limit was increased from 20 to 24 weeks in order to reduce unsafe abortion and maternal mortality.

Topic: Medical termination of pregnancy

Reference: MOHFW guidelienes, the rules of MTP (Amendment) act,2021

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese nulliparous patient presents with abnormal uterine bleeding. An office endometrial biopsy was performed which was indicating well differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma. MRI of the patient concluded a tumor invading the cervical stroma but not extending beyond the uterus. What is the ideal treatment plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario indicates a stage 2 endometrial cancer.

Three areas must be addressed in any treatment plan:

  1. For optimal results, the uterus should be removed in all patients.
  2. Because the incidence of pelvic lymph node metastases is about 36% in stage II endometrial cancer, any treatment protocol should include treatment of these lymph nodes.
  3. Because the incidence of disease spread outside the pelvis to the para-aortic lymph nodes, adnexal structures, and upper abdomen is higher than in stage I disease, attention should be directed to evaluating and treating extrapelvic disease.

Two approaches usually were used in the treatment of clinical stage II disease:

  1. Radical hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and pelvic and paraaortic lymphadenectomy
  2. Combined radiation and surgery (external pelvic radiation and intracavitary radium or cesium followed in 6 weeks by total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy)

Topic: endometroid adenocarcinoma

Reference: Berek & Novak's Gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 37, Page number:2386

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Table to remember findings of ovarian tumor.

Topic: ovarian tumors

Reference: Berek & Novak's Gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 39, Page number.2660

questions.text: A patient came to obstetrics and Gynecology OPD having a history of G2P1A0L1 + 1 month 18 days of amenorrhea. In her previous pregnancy there was spontaneous preterm birth, what is the ideal supportive treatment in this pregnancy for this patient:
questions.solution:
H/O preterm birth + short cervix <25 mm-> treatment is cervical cerclage + progesterone supplementation.

H/O previous preterm birth -> treatment is progesterone supplementation only.

H/O short cervix + no preterm birth in past -> treatment is progesterone supplementation only.

When using vaginal progesterone, start treatment betwee

16+0 and 24+0 weeks of pregnancy and continue until at least 34 weeks.

Topic: previous spontaneous preterm birth history

Reference: NICE guidelines 2022 for Preterm labour and birth, page number: 7

questions.text: Pain in endometriosis correlates with:
questions.solution:
There is no relationship with site, stage or morphology of endometriosis and pain.

Possible mechanisms causing pain in patients with endometriosis include local peritoneal inflammation, deep infiltration with tissue damage, adhesion formation, fibrotic thickening, and collection of shed menstrual blood in endometriotic implants, resulting in painful traction with the physiologic movement of tissues

Topic: endometriosis

Reference: Berek & Novak's Gynecology, 16th Edition, Page number: 680

questions.text: In pregnancy colostrum formation starts from
questions.solution:
Breast changes begin at 6 weeks

hyperpigmentation of nipples and areola at 12 weeks

colostrum formation starts at 12 weeks

Topic:colostrum

Reference: William's Obstetrics 25th Edition, chapter 4, page number: 53

questions.text: A 27-year-old Punjabi married female came to a tertiary care hospital with complaints of tachycardia, failure of weight gain despite eating healthy foods at 2 months and 15 days of amenorrhea. On examination exophthalmos and a thyroid swelling was present. The consultant asked to run a thyroid profile of this patient. Patient was diagnosed with hyperthyroidism at 10 weeks of pregnancy. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
• First trimester of pregnancy safe drug - propylthiouracil (50 to 150 gm orally TDS depending upon severity of disease)
  • Second trimester onwards - methimazole
    • Methimazole in first trimester can cause - methimazole embryopathy (esophageal or choanal atresia, aplasia cutis)
    • Usually patients are not transitioned to methimazole in the second trimester if thyroid levels are in range.

Topic: Hyperthyroidism during pregnancy

Reference: William's Obstetrics 25th Edition, chapter 58, page number: 1120

questions.text: In Which of the following conditions in pregnancy is caesarean section preferred over normal vaginal delivery or induction of labor?
questions.solution:
In general, vaginal delivery is preferred and labour induction is safe.

Caesarean delivery is limited to obstetric condition.

Simpson's recommends caesarean delivery for women with:

  1. Dilated aortic root > 4 cm or aortic aneurysm
  2. Acute severe congenital heart failure
  3. Recent myocardial infarction
  4. Severe aortic stenosis
  5. Warfarin administration within 2 weeks of delivery
  6. Need for valve replacement immediately after delivery.

Topic: Caesarean delivery

Reference: William's Obstetrics 25th Edition, chapter 49, page number: 953

questions.text: Identify following instrument-
questions.solution:
Image is showing bird's vacuum cup which has one chain in center and tube in periphery.

Silicon cup is made up of silicon and elastic material. Used more commonly nowadays.

Malmstrom cup is made by the father of vacuum (malmstrom) and it has a chain and tube both in the center.

Kiwi cup is a soft flexible omnicup which expands and molds to the fetal head.

Topic:Bird's vaccum cup

Reference: William's Obstetrics 25th Edition, chapter 29, page number: 562

questions.text: 35-year-old primigravida patient came to OPD with her usg finding suggestive of absent nasal bone. Which of following is next step to rule out trisomy?
questions.solution:
Chorionic villus sampling is performed between 10 -13 weeks of gestation by transabdominal or transcervical route. Results come earlier.

Amniocentesis is performed between 15-20 weeks by transabdominal route. Amniocytes should be cultured before the procedure so results are late.

Cordocentesis is performed after 18 weeks by transabdominal route.

Fetal skin biopsy is not recommended method for prenatal diagnosis

Topic:chorionic villus sampling

Reference: William's Obstetrics 25th Edition, chapter 14, page number.293

questions.text: All of the followings are contraindication for tocolysis except:
questions.solution:
Contraindication for tocolysis are:

  • Intrauterine death
  • Non reassuring fetal heart
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Lethal fetal nomaly
  • Haemodynamically unstable mother
  • Gestational age > 34 weeks
  • Severe preeclampsia or eclampsia

Preterm labour is the indication of tocolysis

Topic:tocolysis

Reference: ACOG Practice Bulletin 171, box 1

questions.text: G5P4A0L4 patient came with complain of weakness, palpitation, chest pain. On examination she has tachycardia. her tongue, nail and conjunctiva are pale. On investigation her HB-7 gm/dl with peripheral smear suggestive of microcytic hypochromic cells. Which of the following is most sensitive laboratory investigation in this condition?
questions.solution:
This case is of iron deficiency anemia.

Most sensitive lab investigation for iron deficiency anemia: sr. ferritin

Most sensitive red cell index for iron deficiency anemia is MCHC.

Classic morphological evidence of iron-deficiency anemia is erythrocyte hypochromia and microcytosis. This may be less prominent in the pregnant woman. Serum ferritin levels are lower. And, levels of hepcidin-the master regulator of iron availability-are decreased normally in pregnancy.

Topic:iron deficiency anemia

Reference: William's Obstetrics 25th Edition, chapter 56, page number:1077

choices.text: First time after 48 hours of delivery

questions.text: Atypical preeclampsia occurs:
questions.solution:
Atypical preeclampsia indicates preeclampsia before 20 weeks or for the first time after 48 hours of delivery. It can occur in molar pregnancy or antiphospholipid syndrome.

Topic:Atypical preeclampsia

Reference: NICE guidelines (NG133), Hypertension in pregnancy: diagnosis and management

questions.text: A 32-year-old Muslim married female, residing in Saraspur, came to a tertiary care hospital at 9:30 am, with complaints of 4 episodes of seizures at home. The first episode commenced at 3:30 am in the morning. The obstetric history of the patient is: G4P3A0L3 + 7 months and 26 days of amenorrhea, previous three full term normal vaginal delivery. On examination: P: 100/min, BP: 190/120 mmhg, PA: 30 weeks, cephalic floating, Fetal heart rate 130 bpm, PV: is closed, no show, no leak. On her dipstick urine examination, her urine albumin was +4. All of the following drugs are used in case of eclampsia as antihypertensives except:
questions.solution:
• Dangerous hypertension can cause cerebrovascular hemorrhage and hypertensive encephalopathy, and it can trigger eclamptic convulsions in women with preeclampsia. Other complications include placental abruption and congestive heart failure induced by elevated hypertensive afterload.
  • Because of these serious sequelae, the working group for the National High Blood Pressure Education Program (NHBPEP)
  • (2000) and the 2013 Task Force recommend treatment to lower systolic pressures to or below 160 mm Hg and diastolic pressures to or below 110 mm Hg.
  • Magnesium sulfate is not given to treat hypertension. It is used for anticonvulsant action on the cerebral cortex.

Rest all the options are antihypertensive drugs.

Topic: Antihypertensives in Eclampsia

Reference: William's Obstetrics 25th Edition, chapter 40, page number: 736

questions.text: Stallworthy sign is seen in
questions.solution:
Stallworthy sign seen in posterior placenta previa (dangerous placenta previa) - it is slowing of fetal heart by pressing head downwards.

Topic:stallworthy sign

Reference: William's Obstetrics 25th Edition, chapter 41, page number:775
